lines.text: How'd you scrape your knuckles?
Shadowboxing a lamppost.
[after a pause]
I got a little pissed last night.

[offering Reardon a cigarette from his mouth in the prison yard]
Here you are.

[Reardon hesitates]
Take it. I've only got syph.
What're you in for?
Mopery.

[Reardon turns around]
Exposing yourself to a blind woman.
If there's anything else you need, just press this button here.

[smiling]
Yeah!

[after a pause]
I'd like a poke.
A poke, Mr. Reardon?
Yeah, a poke. You know what i mean. How about it, Stretch?

[smiling]
I'm afraid I stopped being a woman several years ago.
Get someone else.
No, that's not possible.
Why not?
Security obviously.
I don't have to talk to her.
Well, even if she didn't speak, she would see you.
Put a bag over her head.
But you would see her.
Put a bag over my head. I've been in prison for 15 months!

[musing poetically]
I'm going home.
[quoting poetry]
'Sleep after toil, port after stormy seas, ease after war, death after life does greatly please.'

[laconically]
I don't know about you, Slade; I'm not ready for death. The rest I'll drink to.

[speaking of the gravely injured Mackintosh]
There is a letter. He always writes one. It's to be given to the Prime Minister in case of his death.
Well, who's got it?
His solicitor.
Well, get it! Tell him it's an emergency!
An act of Parliament couldn't open that envelope before he dies.
Fly to London. Smother Mackintosh with his pillow.
No, I wouldn't do that. He's my father.

[to Reardon]
I like to study the workings of the criminal mind at close quarters whenever I have the opportunity, so please speak out.
Even the best of politicians have to compromise sometimes.
Our deaths would mean little or nothing to anyone, anywhere - only to ourselves.
